text:
ah i'm getting a duplicate key error ever since i had some failed transfer offer attempts in the wallet ui

``` {"@timestamp":"2025-07-25T11:06:58.448Z","@version":"1","message":"Restarting ledger ingestion loop after 30 seconds due to unexpected exception:","logger_name":"o.l.s.a.UpdateIngestionService:validator=validator_backend/endUserParty=the_tie_validator::1220d3016091/ingestionLoopFor=DbUserWalletStore","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-23","level":"INFO","level_value":20000,"stack_trace":"org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint \"user_wallet_txlog_store_si_ti_ei_key\"\n  Detail: Key (store_id, tx_log_id, event_id)=(2, txh, #122076351de2ae0876adbdf99248ca2b86aa67df838b40b7d79ec61c39b89f14550d:0) already exists```
how can I resolve? I don't want to just delete rows in postgres without knowing what the consequence may be etc.

elements.text: ah i'm getting a duplicate key error ever since i had some failed transfer offer attempts in the wallet ui

{"@timestamp":"2025-07-25T11:06:58.448Z","@version":"1","message":"Restarting ledger ingestion loop after 30 seconds due to unexpected exception:","logger_name":"o.l.s.a.UpdateIngestionService:validator=validator_backend/endUserParty=the_tie_validator::1220d3016091/ingestionLoopFor=DbUserWalletStore","thread_name":"canton-env-ec-23","level":"INFO","level_value":20000,"stack_trace":"org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint \"user_wallet_txlog_store_si_ti_ei_key\"\n  Detail: Key (store_id, tx_log_id, event_id)=(2, txh, #122076351de2ae0876adbdf99248ca2b86aa67df838b40b7d79ec61c39b89f14550d:0) already exists
how can I resolve? I don't want to just delete rows in postgres without knowing what the consequence may be etc.

text: Ideally when you restore the DB you pull a copy of the participant DB that is more recent than the validator DB and the node should recover without needing to use identity file

elements.text: Ideally when you restore the DB you pull a copy of the participant DB that is more recent than the validator DB and the node should recover without needing to use identity file

text: Restoring a single snapshot may work but I believe there can be edge cases where components may not have fully written to their databases and thus participant could be seen to be earlier than validator. This might not restore properly.

elements.text: Restoring a single snapshot may work but I believe there can be edge cases where components may not have fully written to their databases and thus participant could be seen to be earlier than validator. This might not restore properly.

text: Not sure what you’re referencing. A “validator” consists of a participant node and a validator node. Both have PG databases

elements.text: So for after installation we only got 1 DB configured, and used from Validator and Participant

text: <https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_helm.html#installing-the-helm-charts>

I don’t recall the exact terms used but agree - you have a single instance of PostgresQL with several DBs within the instance. The participant and the validator app connect to the different Dbs within the instance

elements.text: I don’t recall the exact terms used but agree - you have a single instance of PostgresQL with several DBs within the instance. The participant and the validator app connect to the different Dbs within the instance

text: Ideally the participant DB is restored from a more recent backup than the validator app db within the same instance of PG

elements.text: Ideally the participant DB is restored from a more recent backup than the validator app db within the same instance of PG

text: I am getting what you say. A full storage snapshot from Postgres instance would be enough, right?

elements.text: I am getting what you say. A full storage snapshot from Postgres instance would be enough, right?

text: In most cases yes. However I believe that there are edge cases where either the participant and validator don’t write to their DBs immediately (caching, etc) and the instance level backup may not be usable. I am trying to get more clarity of the exact circumstances myself.

elements.text: In most cases yes. However I believe that there are edge cases where either the participant and validator don’t write to their DBs immediately (caching, etc) and the instance level backup may not be usable. I am trying to get more clarity of the exact circumstances myself.

text: That said, how can I recover 100% after a disaster?

elements.text: That said, how can I recover 100% after a disaster?

text: My experience is there is no single answer to that question. Ensure that you take DB backups regularly, identity backups, build out a DR / test plan and execute this regularly in an environment that matches production. In the final case investigate tools like Canton repair commands, though these should only be used after all other options are exhausted. There is a lot of experience across the Canton Network community and within Digital Asset to assist.

elements.text: My experience is there is no single answer to that question. Ensure that you take DB backups regularly, identity backups, build out a DR / test plan and execute this regularly in an environment that matches production. In the final case investigate tools like Canton repair commands, though these should only be used after all other options are exhausted. There is a lot of experience across the Canton Network community and within Digital Asset to assist.
